captions.text: Every year it&#39;s the bloody same.

Oh, the midyear drought isn&#39;t so bad, I&#39;ll
just do indie games on steam and retros and

laugh at an industry that never learns anything
tee hee hee.

And now we&#39;re in the middle of it and I&#39;m
desperately searching under sunbleached rocks

looking for something that isn&#39;t slathered
in anime faces like a row of electrical sockets.

You know, I even seriously considered reviewing
No Man&#39;s Sky again now it&#39;s apparently been

patched all the way from universally despised
pariah to the lofty heights of another bloody
survival crafting exploration game.
But no.

It&#39;s against my principles to encourage this
&quot;let&#39;s just fix it in post&quot; culture, that
is not a world in which I wish to exist.

Because I would never be able to have confidence
in a negative review again.

A game could melt my PC into hot slag until
it falls over and sets fire to the curtains,

I&#39;d still have to add the proviso &quot;Oh but
it&#39;s alright because in the future they might
patch in a new pair of curtains.&quot;

So fuck it, in the end I decided to review
a game I missed out on from last year that

popped up on my Steam recommendations apropos
of nothing like a starry-eyed young actor
showing up on the last day of auditions.

Observer is a game by Bloober Team, no really,
that&#39;s their name, sounds to me like someone

asked them their name before they&#39;d come up
with it and someone had to hastily make one
up, same developers as Layers of Fear.

Which you may recall I didn&#39;t take to much
because it was a classic walking simulator

with all the usual walking simulator trappings
- deliberately obscure plot and it&#39;s only

the continued brain-busting challenge of locating
the &#39;W&#39; key on your keyboard that stops it

being essentially the same as riding the Haunted
Mansion ride at Disneyland.

Observer, in contrast, plays like a first
person adventure game that&#39;s currently in
rehab for walking simulator addiction.

It&#39;s gradually rebuilding its life one dialogue
tree or basic lock opening puzzle at a time,
but every now and again it falls off the wagon.

And if Layers of Fear came of riding the Haunted
Mansion ride a few too many times, Observer
comes of rewatching Blade Runner every night.

Cyberpunk dystopia, check - you know, just
for once I&#39;d like to see a cyberpunk Utopia,

where the corporations started bolting computers
to people&#39;s faces and everything just worked

out perfectly well - main character&#39;s a detective,
check,

completely unnecessary opening text crawl
which might as well have been replaced with

the words &quot;it is a cyberpunk dystopia&quot;, check,
Rutger Hauer&#39;s in it, double check with chips
on the side.

Rutger Hauer, who now talks like he&#39;s processing
all his words through a slightly blunt hand-cranked

ice crushing machine, is an Observer, a sort
of cyber detective with the ability to jack

off - I mean, jack INTO other people&#39;s brains
in order to search their memories for evidence
of dirty crimes.
And whatever else should be of interest.
Perhaps jack off was right after all.

Anyway, our hero, Daniel Lazarski, which is
one of those surnames that sounds just perfect

being described as a loose cannon across the
desk of a sweaty police chief, is contacted

by his estranged tech genius son who probably
stopped calling because he was sick of explaining
to Rutger Hauer how to use Facebook.

But something&#39;s gone to shit and he needs
help so dear old Dad comes to the slum apartment

building his son was calling from, finds a
whole bunch of crime scenes and dead bodies

and must piece together exactly what his son
was doing and what it has to do with the evil

megacorporation that inevitably hangs over
everything like the highly productive rectum
of a pitiless controller God.

By jacking into the minds of a select number
of victims, so basically it&#39;s Blade Runner
meets Psychonauts.
Meets the Haunted Mansion ride.

You know, detective games have long struggled
with the concept of &#39;investigative&#39; gameplay.

How do you make a gameplay mechanic based
around the player figuring stuff out that

can determine that the player actually did
figure it out and isn&#39;t just rolling a belt

sander back and forth across the controller
until progress happens?

Observer takes a bold approach to this age
old problem, and that&#39;s to not let it bother
them in the slightest.

So while you go over crime scenes with three
different pairs of magic electronic spectacles

holding down the analyse button on anything
that makes one of your spectacles go widdly

wee, what usually happens after you&#39;ve widdly
weed everything that can be widdly weed is

that Rutger Hauer announces he&#39;s figured it
out and the door to the next bit opens.

Either that or there&#39;ll be a four digit code
lock you need to figure out, but the game
makes sure no one gets left behind.

There is literally a moment when the numbers
you need to figure out materialise before
you in giant neon digits.

Another time, I was casually jacking off into
the head of a dead young lady in a room with

a conspicuous four digit code lock, and towards
the end of the jack off sequence I see the
same lady in the same room going &quot;6105!
6105!&quot;

So once I was back in reality I went back
to the code lock flush with pride at my deductive

reasoning skills, but before I could do anything
Rutger Hauer went &quot;I THINK THE CODE MIGHT

WHAT DO YOU THINK, ELECTRONIC GENIUSES OF
THE FUTURE?&quot;

So despite its handful of puzzles and explorative
element where you wander the mazelike hallways

of the apartment building having arguments
with random people&#39;s door intercoms in a way

that screams &quot;We didn&#39;t want to have to design
more than, like, three characters&quot;, Observer
is still elbow deep in walking simulator land.

The jack off sequences are the moments when
the walking simulator leaps off the bench

rubbing its hands together with glee and I&#39;m
tempted to use the word &#39;overindulgent&#39; as

well as the word &#39;cuntblast&#39; but that&#39;s for
unrelated reasons.

So with the justification that we&#39;re exploring
a dying person&#39;s mental realm stitched together

from unreliable memories all the old Layers
of Fear reality buggeration comes back in

force, spooky happenings and illogical geography
galore.

But again it&#39;s just Haunted Mansion press
forward to continue and I keep hearing random

audio stings because apparently something
sudden and jumpscarey happened while I was
looking at something else.

But then on, like, three occasions during
jackoff bits Mr. Gameplay wakes up with a

start, sees that Mr. Walking Simulator has
been running unchecked for like an hour and
goes &quot;Shit!

Er... here&#39;s a monster, stealth around it
or something I guess.&quot;

But I&#39;ve been settling into a light puzzling
cum sightseeing tour groove for the last several

hours so this sudden risk of instakill game
over is very bloody jarring.

If you wanted to sprinkle gameplay into your
haunted mansion ride then I&#39;d have put some

kind of comprehension test at the end, to
see if we&#39;d figured out that the exploding

jackdaw with the head of Bruce Forsyth was
supposed to symbolise that the subject didn&#39;t
get on with their dad growing up.

But in summary, I&#39;d say I like Observer quite
a bit more than Layers of Fear, and it&#39;s mainly

because, fun as it may be to explore the visual
artistry of the interactive medium by throwing

plates at our head as we walk down a hallway,
a nice bit of context and grounding in reality

can work wonders, and a little puzzle or gameplay
challenge can really help us refocus when
we&#39;ve been dazed by a flying sugar bowl.

It&#39;s just finding the right blend of elements,
now.
Exploration mechanics, yes.
Jarring instakill monster interludes, cuntblast.
